channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: 2025 in review: Insta influencers, murder trials, and divisive politics
item.description: Lowy Institute staff nominate the most notable books, trends, ideas, and people of 2025.

item.title: Two new books on the future of globalisation
item.description: Globalisation has always had ups and downs, and has never had clear public support. But trade finds a way.

item.title: Who Will Pay for Russian-Caused Damages in Ukraine?
item.description: A coalition of more than 30 countries has approved a compensation body for assessing Ukrainian reparation claims.

item.title: What’s It Like to Be a Chinese Soldier?
item.description: Behind the parades, recruits face long deployments, strict rules, and limited opportunities.

item.title: How to survive abandonment by America
item.description: Allies are planning for a lonelier, harsher world: a report from South Korea

item.title: Japan’s Prime Minister Takes on Bond Market Vigilantes
item.description: Sanae Takaichi’s massive spending program could be a risky political win.

item.title: Europe Is Racing the Clock to Tap Russia’s Frozen Assets
item.description: Brussels is trying to convince holdouts to support a novel plan to use billions of Moscow’s money to aid Ukraine.

item.title: SpaceX, OpenAI, Anthropic and their giga-IPO dreams
item.description: Will more capital trump more scrutiny?

item.title: One Year on, U.S. Sanctions Are Killing Syria’s Recovery
item.description: Short-term waivers are a start, but Congress must act on the full repeal Syria needs to rebuild.

item.title: Where America’s most prominent short-sellers are placing their bets
item.description: We interview three financial sleuths

item.title: Ethiopia wants to build Africa’s biggest airport
item.description: But conflict, competition and government meddling complicate things

item.title: Getting the AI Story Right
item.description: As AI moves from experimentation to real-world applications, the limits imposed by the physical world, capital markets, and political systems clearly matter more than its theoretical potential. Fortunately, such constraints are not hurdles to progress, but rather the scaffolding behind which it will take shape.

item.title: The race for an AI Jesus is on
item.description: A chatbot offers personalised counsel on faith

item.title: Congress Aims to Turbocharge the U.S. Development Finance Corporation
item.description: The agency will be empowered to issue hundreds of billions of dollars in new loans to foreign countries.

item.title: China’s dispute with India over Arunachal Pradesh
item.description: The detainment in Shanghai of an Indian citizen highlights Beijing’s fixation with controlling narratives of statehood.

item.title: Antitrust Delayed Is Antitrust Denied
item.description: Meta’s recent antitrust win in a high-profile case brought by US regulators illustrates the challenges of reactive measures. Taking a preventive approach – namely, challenging mergers when they are first proposed – is a better way to prevent the emergence of monopolies in fast-moving tech markets.

item.title: National Cabinet Agrees to Sweeping Overhaul of Australia’s Gun Laws in Response to Bondi Massacre
item.description: After the attack on Australia’s Jewish community, the government is undertaking the biggest overhaul of national gun laws since 1996. Critics say it's a deflection from the real issue: antisemitism.

item.title: Hong Kong Pro-Democracy Publisher Convicted of Sedition in Major Blow to Press Freedom
item.description: Jimmy Lai and his Apple Daily once symbolized Hong Kong’s free press. His conviction under the National Security Law is the death knell for that democratic ideal.

item.title: Australia: Regionalism as a Nexus to Great Power Politics
item.description: The alliance with the U.S. remains central to Canberra’s strategy, but it is also attempting to construct more independent, regionally-led security initiatives.

item.title: The Trump Administration’s Epochal Shift on Foreign Aid
item.description: The change to funding governments instead of NGOs is long overdue but could easily go wrong.

item.title: Daddy Trump
item.description: In the 1970s, citizens of the Soviet Union scoffed at Leonid Brezhnev’s demented vanity, his insatiable need for praise, and the obsequiousness of his entourage. But it was nothing compared to the self-aggrandizing behavior of Donald Trump and the sycophancy of his enablers.

item.title: America gives Ukraine reason to hope, just
item.description: The latest peace proposals are only a bit closer to what Ukraine and Europe need

item.title: The Irresistible Temptation of Chile’s Polarized Politics
item.description: Four years ago, Chileans were tempted by the promise of a progressive “refoundation” of the country under Gabriel Boric, a former student leader, and elected him president. Now they have swung in the opposite direction, electing the far-right José Antonio Kast – and are likely to be equally disappointed.

item.title: China’s 2025 White Paper on Latin America Sets the Stage for Renewed Competition With the US
item.description: The new document declared China’s intention to expand its influence on all fronts, even as the U.S. is turning its focus to the Western Hemisphere.

item.title: Sheikh Hasina’s Spokesperson Mohammad Ali Arafat on the ICT’s ‘Legally Void’ Sentence
item.description: “The death sentence handed down by this kangaroo court is legally void.”

item.title: Turbulence Hits Indian Skies
item.description: Flight cancellations by India’s largest flight operator, IndiGo, threw the domestic aviation sector into chaos early this month.

item.title: Why Japan’s Economic Security Strategy Depends on a Deeper Pivot to Central Asia
item.description: ​The upcoming C5+Japan Summit offers Tokyo its clearest opportunity in two decades to align its foreign policy with its economic-security needs.

item.title: ‘Collective Security’ Is on Life Support
item.description: A basic concept of international relations is under unprecedented strain.

item.title: The Post-Neoliberal Consensus Is Here
item.description: The best that can be said of Trump’s approach to the economy is that it is an experimental phase in the post-neoliberal transition. The good news is that future policymakers will not have to look far for new guiding principles.

item.title: Why Indonesia Cancelled the Early Retirement of the Cirebon-1 Power Plant
item.description: As predicted, the early retirement of coal-fired power plants has run aground on the country's political economic realities.

item.title: Southeast Asia’s Year in Review
item.description: Tracking the region’s biggest developments in 2025.

item.title: How to Survive in a Multialigned World
item.description: The Indian way of strategic diversification.

item.title: Latin America’s Revolution of the Right
The Allies After America
item.description: In search of Plan B.

item.title: China’s Long Economic War
item.description: How Beijing builds leverage for indefinite competition.

item.title: The Illiberal International
item.description: Authoritarian cooperation is reshaping the global order.

item.title: The Weakness of the Strongmen
The Dark Side of China’s Success
item.description: A Response to “The Real China Model”

item.title: The Illusion of Nuclear Deterrence
item.description: A Response to “Europe’s Bad Nuclear Options”

item.title: Hope and redemption at Bondi Beach
item.description: Finding meaning for Australia in a despicable act of terrorism.

item.title: Malaysia Postpones Special ASEAN Meeting on Thailand-Cambodia Conflict
item.description: The move came as China's government urged both nations to exercise "utmost restraint” and de-escalate tensions.
